NAPOLÉON BONAPARTE, drame en 6 actes, par Alex.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.sentence:
NAPOLÉON BONAPARTE, drame en 6 actes, par Alexandre Dumas; texte d'après une notice ayant ete communiquée par l'auteur a André CHÉNIER, (fils de Marie-Joseph, le geographe) éditée dans le premier volume des lettres de SHERIDAN.


PTAC REVIEWER'S COMMENTS:


The fact that the telegraph is spelled incorrectly at the beginning indicates that the document has integrity,
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT:". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

LE NAUFRAGE DE LA MÉDUSE, drame en 5 actes.

prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.

backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. prediction.sentence:
Dumas, Thomas F. The Colored Line; or, The Rats-Fatter and the Mole-Trapper. Cincinnati: Tribune Printing & Lithographing Co., 1916.

Revision of volume 3 of "American State Trials" to include complete information presented at trial and subsequent proceedings, reviews of the trial by experts from outside the legal system, information from newspaper coverage and other writings, and unpublished source material obtained from private collection, as well as photographs of some of the characters involved.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT:". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

PARIS LA NUIT, idem.

PARIS LA NUIT, 25 AVRIL 1839.

SOCIÉTÉ OVULAMPIQUE.
PARIS LA NUIT.


For many years, madame Sophie de Segur and M. Chabrillac urged on the Academy of Sciences to proceed at once to the translation and publication of the works which had been left by François Huber, director of the domain of Neuchâtel from 1792 to 1817.


In the year 1829 the
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.

backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy

We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT:". TEXT TO CORRECT:
PARIS LE BOHÉMIEN, idem.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.sentence: Paris le Bohémien, ou chansons [et] airs de Bohème, par Maurice Schlesinger, direction musicale Philippe Raspail [et] Bruno Coulais.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.

prediction.sentence:
In 5 acts.

"MUSIQUE DE LA PRODUZIONE NATIONALE ITALIANA" ("literally: Music of the National production of Italian", a label by EMI, c. 1916-1924) and the reissue label of the same ("EMI 20th CENTURY") are used to give music bibliographic reference to Italian symphonic music records made between the last decades of the 1800's and the first decades of the 1900's.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

prediction.sentence:
LA PENSIONNAIRE MARIÉE, vaud.


REPORT PHOENIXVILLE SPECIAL.
PC Leeds, Daisy and their month-old daughter, Lynwood, came to Phoenixville late Saturday afternoon when Mr. and Mrs. Leeds, residing in Bethlehem, were summoned to the death bed of Mrs. Leeds' mother. Mrs. Jacob Ethey, 40, mother of Mrs. Leeds, passed away early Saturday morning in her home near Bethlehem.

Funeral services for Mrs. Ethey will be held Tuesday morning

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c

a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy

The first Czechoslovak
newspaper was printed in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania in 1929 by the Union of Czechs working in the United States. It was published biweekly for more than a year and had a circulation of 6,000. Another publication was called "Kurierti" of the New York "Družina" and appeared twice in 1936.

After the Renaissance, the Czech language Arts and Sciences movement of Culture of the living

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

prediction.prompt:
Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT:". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
PIERRE LEROUGE, com.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.sentence:
PIERRE NOEL LEROUGE, cor.


Source (further forks welcome): https://textcorparchives.wordpress.com/test-corpus/cca2.html

James
1. You have reviewed and corrected the following text: 
COLOMBO, 20 ful-L by 10 im-L, very badly. 28.7.82.
BOARDING-HOUSE 
BY M. E. LEROUGE
SYNOPSIS.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

prediction.sentence:
In 5 acts.

"MUSIQUE DE LA PRODUZIONE NATIONALE ITALIANA" ("literally: Music of the National production of Italian", a label by EMI, c. 1916-1924) and the reissue label of the same ("EMI 20th CENTURY") are used to give music bibliographic reference to Italian symphonic music records made between the last decades of the 1800's and the first decades of the 1900's.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. [Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. [Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

prediction.sentence:
Souldié.

Accented vowels are indicated with an acute mark: á, é, è, ê, î, ô, ù. 
Accented consonants are indicated with a cedilla: ç, é, è, ê, î, ô, ù.

e.g. pièce — piece

Soulié is also a surname:
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

QUI SE RESSEMBLE SE GÊNE, village, cant. de St-Bernard (La Gruyère), arr. de Poliez. 2,490 hab. Le village est sur une hauteur; les potiers y ont de vieux établissemens, des propriétés très-considérables; le sol est ferrugineux. De petits ouvrages y complètent les grands.

prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

prediction.sentence:
RICHE ET PAUVRE, drame en 5 actes, par Emile Souvestre
JEANNE LA FRIPIÉE, drame en 5 actes.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.

Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.
