ROMÉO ET JULIETTE, par Frédéric Soulié.


Frédéric Soulié, Juliette ou la Passion parisienne, nouvelle dramatique en 3 actes, représentée pour la première fois, au Théâtre de l'Odéon, le 3 mars 1848.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy

We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
STELLA, ou la Forteresse du Mont des Géants, drame en 5 actes.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.sentence:
STELLA, ou la Forteresse du Mont des Géants, drame en 5 actes, en vers.






No performance records of this work are currently available. If you would like to contribute information, please contact "aagenaes@us.es" or write to "Anthony Aagenaes, Forum for Music Research , Dept. of Musicology, University of Oslo, P. O. Box 1048 Blindern, N-0313 Oslo, Norway".
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

prediction.sentence:
LE TREMBLEMENT DE TERRE DE LA MARTINIQUE ou La Mort du volcan.
Contes noirs.



For now, 150 stories are available, covering the period from 1850 to 1905. Please reload this page in order to consult the other available stories.

This project it's an initiative from the Martinique's Ministry of Culture and the Departmental Council of Martinique in order to promote the local literary heritage. Published works are made available in digital format thanks to the scanning of old book from public libraries and generosity of owners.
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

prediction.sentence:
Thomas Maurevert, idem.

The President of the Tribunal, having explained the nature of the proceeding, declared it closed.
After reviewing each of the four guillotined individuals, only 1 Thomas Bresciani (a native of Annonay, aged 57, and orphan of fatherland), was found innocent of being a traitor to France and murder of a French soldier. He was set free by the Tribunal of Annunciation to return to his family, with every possible recommendation to maintain himself in a non-
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

prediction.sentence:
UN MARIAGE SOUS LOUIS XV, comédie en 3 actes et 3 tableaux par Alexandre Dumas.


MORALE POLICÈRES— ACTE II.



LES ARISTOCRATES, MONSIEUR DE COMINES, CAUGIAU-LENCI WOLF, BIRNSTACH, GARIBALDI,


Et tant d'autres encore.


LES VICTIMES: JABOTARD ET RAPHAËL, LES
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. Dumas, Thomas F. The Colored Line; or, The Rats-Fatter and the Mole-Trapper. Cincinnati: Tribune Printing & Lithographing Co., 1916.

Revision of volume 3 of "American State Trials" to include complete information presented at trial and subsequent proceedings, reviews of the trial by experts from outside the legal system, information from newspaper coverage and other writings, and unpublished source material obtained from private collection, as well as photographs of some of the characters involved.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.

Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

UNE VISION DU TASSE, monologue en 1 a.

prediction.sentence:
EXT. BRAZILIAN FOREST, NIGHT.


It is peaceful and peaceful in Ipanapo´s house. The Indian guides will put her next to the bed confidences. The hall door night is open. Light falls on a table and among the cushions that turn it into an oasis of rest. The child sleeps in one of them.

The maid opens a lattice and takes Ipanapo to her room by the hand. Arrives the son, the black Ruy.

He throws himself on the
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

prediction.sentence:
Edith J. Rissien.


APPENDIX 1


SUPPLEMENTARY TABLE OF ENGAGEMENTS


There are presently five known performances of “La Fille aux Yeux d’Or” in which Adam played Strephon.

———1843 (1) Paris, Odeon-Théâtre, Artistamatique [V], 31 January, J.I. Ribot, Adam? d'Arvey-Charles Hérold*, Fanny Biasin,
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c

a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.

backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

prediction.sentence: BEAUTY, SATIRE, AND THE ARTS
prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c

a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.

A Paris, chez Souveraineté, rue Neuve-des-Petits-Champs, près les Théâtres, et chez l'auteur.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c

a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript

Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.

backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy

We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.

prediction.region:
[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.


Backside of a broadsheet concerning the collision between the Spanish warship "Actevi " and the brig "Le Jénéral Convoi," fishing in Spanish waters.


Backside of a broadsheet of August 30 and 31, 1852, concerning fortifying the entrances to the capital.


Backside of broadsheet concerning the visit of

Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT:". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

LE MARIAGE DE FIGARO, comédie en 5 actes.

One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.

[Ballanche, novel writer, lived on rue Saint-Louis—now: 1st arrondissement—3, near Pont Sully and Temple Barracks, and also for a while on rue Musette (Not printed.) 1.41 JACOMINI, [brother] Bernard, directeur de la Sorbonne (de 1849 a 1871), born in Paris, November 1, 1806; entered the Congregation of the Fathers of Mercy (which he left in 1835); composed for the stage; decided to devote himself to letters and went in 1839 to Grenoble where Gresset styled him "adorable lovely old man." _TRAITS D'ENC, drame en 3 actea JACQUELINE SERVO, drame en 3 actes. (de 1849 a 184c


NOTES:


a. Bibliothèque Nationale, D.I.1.20.3, which is to appear.


b. Alexandre Dumas fils, Souvenirs de jeunesse ( Paris, 1883), II. 65 n. Viardot writes to Dumas: " That comes from the anecdote of the "little stick "(plantoir). One day Madame Récamier was pregnant, at least so they said, and to avoid all scandal, she gave notice to her mother and to the poor curé who had officiated at her marriage and who still visited her. When the poet Chénier wished to enter, the old woman received him as she would anybody who came by who was not inscribed in front. He said to Dumas: "Voilà Villot et Villotne, petit plantoir et grand plantoir," quoting a passage from their tragedy. The next day all of social life was discussing the joke at Madame Récamier s expense."


c. VI, 292. Dumas then travels via the major Italian cities to England.


d. IV, 128 and 264. A narrow escape from bandits who attacked their coach.


e. Dumas meets the young novelist and former inspector general of secondary education Léon Gozlan, with whom he will be on excellent terms in 1851 and who introduces him to author Charles Anger( 1810-1868), whom he does not seem to know at this point. The work of Anger had been circulated by his father in manuscript


VI, 303


Backside of a leaf from D.I.3.19, concerning Bibliothèque Nationale, D.l.46.a No.4. The Interior of the cab (IV, 74) is most likely the descriptions of the view of Porto-Fino found in IV, 77. Dumas has described the journey back home to Grosvenor Street, his arrest on the way, the questionings by police, the examination by a justice of the peace.


Backside of a broadsheet of the VII, 19 signature (IV, 96), "the execution of John Brown." This leaf concerns the trial of the abolitionist John Brown on trial from Nov. 2 1859 until December 2.


Elizabeth Barrett Browning becomes ill.


Backside of a broadsheet of the 13 of November, 1859, touching on the trial of Brown, who was condemned to death on December 2.


The newly elected president, Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is visited by many European writers including Dumas, Lamartine, Balzac, and Gustave Flaubert, who writes to his mother on November 29, 1859, describing the tense U.S. atmosphere.


backside of a broadsheet of January 3, 1858. The Alexandre Dumas Theater company is transferred to the Odéon, having lost the right to perform in the Comedy


Broadside of French political scandal, the scandale de Panama, where Dumas, as a member of the Chamber of the Deputies was an interested party. Karl Marx described the occasion as "the most shameless ballyhoo and brazen corruption stunt ever heard on the face of the earth."


We go from the graphic and satirical image of revolution to a striking image of the battle in Washington which appeared in Punch, a British magazine to which Dumas subscribed.


Broadside with information about the escape of Papineau, a fugitive from Canadian justice, and third option for a general constitutional treaty.


Broadsheet concerning the return of emigrants and former political prisoners and Frédéric Chopin.

ALEXANDRE DUMAS
